title: What term better describes social media than social media? - Quora

response.answer_text: Nobody can say that social networks, blogs, forums, microblogging services aren't media. Because we actually use them as media. Obviously they are not media in the traditional meaning: we all know why!  Cause everyone is a potential broadcaster, news producer and spreader, radio station, opinionist, and more. But there's  even more, as Gabriella Sannino wrote. You can value, connect with others, approve, judge, build a reputation. But we should realize that (just) few people used to do that in the past through traditional media, now everyone can!  I think the best term is Social Media for another reason.  The real ''social'' phenomenon is really too complex to be explained in one word, but language help us to create conventions. Social Media is a useful conventional term to indicate a lot of different tools we currently use to commutate ourself in media. Here: http://socialmediatoday.com/intranetworks/255203/what-if-social-media-were-telephones there's another interesting point, strictly correlated with my personal opinion.

Many-to-many communication - describes the fundamental characteristics and effects better than the vague term 'social media'.Examples:Facebook - Many friends communicate directly with many friends in a shared space.Twitter - Many strangers communicate directly with many strangers in a public space. For comparison  One-to-many = Old mediaExample: David Letterman communicates to millions of strangers via television. He can't communicate with his audience directly (react to peoples rants and questions) who are sitting in front of their TV tubes at home.  One-to-one = Direct form of communicationExample: David Letterman has a direct telephone conversation with a friend (private).
